Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area
of security clearances.
Security clearances are necessary for people,
many people who work for the government or work for private
industry that do contracts with the government,
generally the areas of energy and defense.
And what a security clearance means is that government says
that you are okay to look at classified information and feel
that you're not going to divulge this information.
There's different levels of security clearances.
Gay people over the years had a great deal of problems getting
security clearances.
And what we found is that the government's policy in this is
somewhat inconsistent.
They do not have an interagency plan or set of guidelines or
criteria.
Each agency decides on its own.
And there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised.
What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person
get a security clearance. Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I call them the police
agencies, the FBI, the CIA, the National Security Agency, are hanging in there tough and they
will not grant security clearance to anybody they know is gay. There's been some recent
litigation against the CIA. There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the
District of Columbia District Court.
It's before Judge Barrington Parker,
and he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment
in that case for more than a year now.
There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles
in the U.S. District Court down there involving John Green,
who was an engineer with a company known as TRW.
He's worked for TRW, I believe, for 13 years,
and he's never had any problems.
The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information, divulged any information,
but basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay,
and therefore might divulge information.
So that argument breaks down when the person says, I'm not subject to blackmail,
I'm open about my sexuality, my family knows, my friends know, there's no big deal to me,
I don't know why it's a big deal to you, but to the CIA it's still a big deal.
They can't, they just cannot understand why there might be some kind of, or might not
be some kind of problem here.
So that case is pending in the U.S. District Court.
The government just yesterday filed its brief, they filed a motion to dismiss.
They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case based on solemn immunity.
They said the government did not consent to be sued in this case.
And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government
by getting involved in this matter.
They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not.
So they will be responsible for you filing that on March the 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is briefly some First Amendment cases that we're
involved in.
As we find that a number of gay community newspapers,
like here in San Francisco, we have a Bay Area reporter being
censored at a number of prisons around the country.
Prisoners that want to keep in touch with their gay
communities are not being allowed to read these papers.
that we're going to be involved in,
so probably, if we're lucky,
the Congressional Correctional Institute in Kentucky,
and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison,
and possibly one down in Texas as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about
is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well, I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University,

This is where I first got involved in the gay political process, and as a student I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on the main thoroughfare, 40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection.
We wanted to put a banner that said, gay pride week, and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university, we didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared,
because we found out from some of our sources, post administration, that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year,
because they probably would be in some pretty serious trouble.
So the next year, we made an application to put up a ban on women and women not to have any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which
I helped lobby for in 1971, last year they allowed gay students to be kicked out of fraternities
simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole
lot if it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school in another school in Michigan called Andrews College,
which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they were gay.
There's a private college in Southern Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student
who's completed all of his coursework and said this person is gay and he doesn't meet the good moral
character requirements of our schools and he can't handle this degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has official university recognition
to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space
or any funding or any other benefits
that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now
involving the rights of students
to get recognition at their campus.
And my last big gay rights case before I came to the west coast involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
because they were not grand recognition to the undergraduate and to the law school gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involved with students as well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent here in California.
It doesn't have a Sodom statue anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a greater extent may be a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community.
It's sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about.
